review_title: Incredible mission with iffy to completely disorganized departmental management
pros: I had respected Partners In Health as an organization for years before working there. They do a lot of good in the countries they are based in, and they have a large staff of highly qualified global health equity experts. Overall Partners In Health values the opinions and life experience of staff who live in the countries they work in rather than making sweeping assumptions on how the US can help "less developed" countries to consciously try to avoid the white savior complex I have always admired the focus Partners In Health places on centering their work in areas where communities have the least support. By starting administering aid in areas that need it most, PIH tries to solve some of the most difficult problems first, even when it is more difficult to prove the value they provide than if the organization decided to work closer to areas with more resources at the start All this said - These are reasons I admire the mission of Partners In Health, however when I began working there I started to understand why people say you shouldn't meet your idols because they are never quite what they appear to be when they're behind closed doors
cons: I found a lot of the behind the scenes of Partners in Health to be at best disorganized, with thoroughly lackluster onboarding and initial training. The training that new employees do receive is not typically organized through HR, but instead vary greatly depending on the department you join who create their own onboarding materials. I felt I was not given enough information to understand how the parts of the organization which were relevant to my role connected to each other, let alone the overall organization functioned. I worked remotely out of the Boston office (the main US headquarters), working closely with C-level executives as well as representatives of all the countries that Partners In Health has sites in. I was never given any cultural competency training prior to interacting with these high level medical professionals or well known governmental figures. I tried to tread carefully to maintain respect across cultures, but cultural sensitivity/competency training is the absolute least PIH could do to prepare the staff who will be interacting with those working on site in such varied parts of the world. Unfortunately, I also encountered inter-departmental conflicts (more similar to high school drama than to a professional workplace), that my colleagues openly referred to as an ongoing roadblock for collaboration between the teams. Allowing contentious relationships between teams is never going to be conducive to true collaboration, and the insistence on traditional "professionalism" in the org seemed to come to the detriment of real, human communication that could actually address interpersonal problems. Communication between departments within the US office was essential to keeping projects running smoothly, but there was rarely a shared understanding of what other departments were working on, which I would imagine leads to a lot of the same work being done by multiple people who don't know of other initiatives. There was a lot of talk in my time there about "streamlining work flows," "sharing resources," and "increasing communication" between different US departments and between the different country sites, but I never saw any true effort coming from the top to facilitate this There are many die-hard employees at PIH (PIHers) who have been in their roles for decades, which adds a lot of value to the org, but can also give an impression that there are different tiers of employees who receive different levels of respect or who are viewed as more or less valuable based on their tenure, which can leave new employees by the wayside to figure things out on their own rather than "bother" more experienced staff - Laying a foundational understanding that some people's time was definitionally worth more than others even when they are on the same team

review_title: Horrible, Emotionless, & Insensitive Management - Be Ready for a Anxiety & Depression Diagnosis
pros: Hourly pay is amazing! CI makes $30 an hour while CT makes $27 an hour. - Pay may decrease due to the low number COVID-19 cases in MA.

You are expected to make calls every minute. You only get a two15-minute break and one 30 minute break. From there you are expected to be on the phone every minute even if you just got off a 3-hour call and may need a mental break. You can lose your job at any moment due to very minimal reasons such as not logging out properly or using too much sick hours EVENTHOUGH WE ARE IN A PANDEMIC. Supervisors and management are all about numbers so if you are not hitting their mark be ready to be let go. As well, they will not tell you what the mark is so you will be guessing every day what goals you were supposed to meet. There is so much to be said. This job has led to the creation of a private employee chat group to speak freely about our depression and anxiety caused by this job. There have been MANY who have quit and left due to their anxiety and depression from this job. Some have even received diagnoses for this.

pros: Junior and field staff are extremely dedicated to the mission which is inspiring. Nice to be associated with Global Health rockstars such as Dr. Paul Farmer and Dr. Jim Kim.
cons: Disconnected management to junior staff in terms of poor management structure and lack of cohesive, detailed plan to moving the organization forward. For instance, individual teams often pushed forward their own initiatives which meant well but not clear how they fit into any broader strategy. Inability to deal with known deficiencies in healthcare delivery. In one meeting, the Executive Director at the time - Ophelia Dahl - mentioned that PIH was not doing a good job of understanding the social determinants of poverty and how that links to implementing progressive healthcare at field sites. Colleagues in the communications department mentioned friction and disconnect between the development team and the communications department. This is what many other good NGOs are also struggling to deal with. The only important difference between PIH and other good health NGOs was that they were able to raise huge amount of funds due to branding from being associated with Paul Farmer and Jim Kim. Whether this is fair or not depends on one's point of view. Poor growth opportunities for junior staff. HQ location is in an expensive part of Boston.

review_title: More to "Leadership doesn't get it" review
pros: PIH attracts the most dedicated individuals and has a mission like on other!
cons: It has been said, the communication within the organization and from leadership to individual contributors has always left a lot to be desired! Honesty and trust is visibly still lacking  even among the closest colleagues (trying not to offend one another?)  Perhaps the harder the leadership tries in living up to the mission and  diversity and inclusion, the the more this will become part of the culture!  In fact the current CMO-- whose reviews on here have not always been the best-- is the only leader who says the naked truth, attracts and supports minorities to the Boston office,  and forms the long lasting true friendship with colleagues from the countries we work in. She very well knows that you cannot keep saying words "injustice" or "oppression" without naming the oppressor! Thant truth of hers might have hurt some folks overtime through the movies, books etc(perhaps some decided to leave), but there is no other way!

pros:
- Mission is wonderful and a draw for many - particularly more junior - colleagues. 
- Certain colleagues are truly experts in their field (clinical, public health). 
- Big emphasis on cultivating talent from countries in which they work. 
- New office in Boston is very snazzy .
- PIH is well respected within the global health work. Good opportunity for people early in their careers to gain field experience or experience at HQ.
cons:
- Management skills and efforts vary DRAMATICALLY. Some senior colleagues are wonderful, organized and great leaders. Many others are the opposite. I personally experienced harassment and witnessed cronyism coming from multiple men in more senior positions. I raised these issues, but HR capacity also differs dramatically between field offices and HQ. 
- Few opportunities for advancement, especially in the realm of policy and advocacy. 
- Lack of transparency with senior leadership. Leadership needs to have more women and more professional with field experience themselves.

pros:
-The mission to extend and promote healthcare as a human right
-Opportunities to work with smart, passionate people across program areas
-I enjoyed a lot of autonomy to structure and grow my position the way that I wanted, and I learned a lot
-Decent pay and benefits package for country office positions
-Great name recognition in field; helpful for future job searching and networking
cons:
-The cult of personality around certain leaders at the country and HQ level often seemed more important than their ability to effectively do their job
-Lack of transparency around HR processes and protocols. At the country level the hiring process was mysterious, resulting in senior-level hires who were poor fits for their roles. No repercussions for poor performance. Discrepancies in benefits (stipends, vacation time) that often favored male employees who were "favorites" (see Con #1)
-Lack of transparency around country strategy and priorities
-Heavy rotation of outside visitors frequently made day-to-day work challenging

pros: Good way for people from Boston to come to get "Global Health" experience.
cons:
While people are attracted to PIH by a genuine interest to help, the organization is not ready to deploy people in countries in an effective way. 
The organization is carried by the clout (and funding) brought by one individual but has virtually no experienced field managers. The organization doesn't know how to work in coordination with partners, governments or even internally. 
It's one thing to not be constrained by worries about sustainability, it's quite another to be so ineffective in coordination that major initiatives are created in full knowledge that they will end up in failure. In the process, it creates unnecessary complications to deal with, destroys coordination efforts and represents a huge waste of resources. All the while, they continue to write book about Global Health based on their experience mainly in Haiti (which is not always praised in that country), hold gala dinners and talk about their successes...

pros: Mission-driven org doing great work. Founders are inspiring and have the right goals in mind. Board has major players. Some smart and talented internal folks. Efforts to have diversity in staff has shifted for the better. Compensation is generally on par with similar healthcare organizations.
cons: Human resources leadership is very unprofessional and disorganized (we have lost great candidates because they have dropped the ball). Those who went to elite schools are treated better (I am one of them and see it clearly!). Board is not engaged and could be doing so much more from a fundraising standpoint. So much turnover internally for key roles. Departments are siloed and could be doing more together (combining resources, etc). Need a better WFH policy to allow for flexibility, especially for those who can doing their job well remotely.

pros: PIH has a laid-back, collaborative environment. If you are able to professionally assert yourself and be your best advocate, there are plenty of growth opportunities within positions, departments and the organization as a whole. While starting salaries are not necessarily competitive, I was able to work with my manager in my first year at the organization to prove my worth and renegotiate my compensation accordingly.
cons: The inherent downside of working for an organization that says yes to cries for help and works collaboratively with weak government infrastructures is that there are not adequate systems and protocols to support our ever-expanding operations and complicated collaborations. I believe the pros of PIH's moral approach outweigh the cons, but the cons are there and need to be understood. That being said, there are plenty of opportunities to take the initiative to build the needed systems and define lacking protocols.

pros: Absolutely great people. Unique name recognition thanks to the branding effort and ease of getting to the country level.
cons:
I am truly confused but what PIH is trying to achieve. I heard a great vision, but am not seeing something specific come out of it. Our strategies a fussy and fluffy and to make things worse, we seem to have different people working in parallel on the same things without consultation due to egos. 
This is really getting in the way of what we could achieve. I feel like we are still moving a lot of air and not getting concrete enough about getting the most impact for the resources that are entrusted to us.

cons: The need for resources to support the work is enormous so there's a constant focus on budgets which sometimes overwhelms the focus on the mission. Most people work long hours. For better or worse, there's been quite a lot of staff turnover, which is stressful for those who stay.

pros: They bring health care and meds to lands and people no one cares about so that is good.

This organisation has very much lost its soul, its way and its moral compass. Its too bad since it started off with such promise.

review_title: Meaningful work in a toxic environment
job_title: Development and Communications in Boston, MA
pros:
People who work at PIH, especially those who aren't in the executive team, are a pleasure to work with because they are committed to the mission and have interesting experiences. The PIH approach to health care delivery is right on and an excellent thing to learn about and practice if you're interested in global health. It's still to be seen if Gary Gottlieb is the right leader for PIH at this time.

My advice for junior staff is to negotiate your salary (HR is not to be trusted on equitable fair pay), advocate for greater responsibility and promotions that will benefit your long-term career, and plan on spending no more than two-three years there before moving on to something else you are excited about. Also, limit your friendships with co-workers to avoid gossip that will make you lose faith in the leadership team - and do your part not to promote gossip. Have a life outside of PIH.
cons: Partners In Health is a toxic working environment because managers' actions so often do not align with the PIH values and mission, which is what attracts most junior staff to work there. Meanwhile, the seriousness of the mission and the culture of self-sacrifice may make you take failures personally, when it's not your fault. It's a chaotic and dysfunctional work environment, due to secrecy, cronyism, poorly thought out decisions in an unclear decision-making structure, consolidation of power in founders, executives, and people who have relationships with the founders, drastically different ideas of how PIH should operate, and rampant mistrust of executives. Turnover is extraordinarily high; most junior staff do not stay more than 2-3 years. Even people in the leadership team have been turning over (some thankfully).

pros: The atmosphere at Partners in Health is one in which everyone with whom you'll work actively believe in the organization's mission. I was challenged with difficult projects that required me to interact with people from different departments, and I was blown away by how committed and inspirational each of the employees is.
cons: If you do not believe in or are not inspired by the right to health movement, you'll find that the PIH mission dominates the ideology of the organization. Also, depending on your position, you may have to stay late to work.

review_title: Terrible management. Do not work here.
pros: Prestige, ability to work from home
cons:
Management is incredibly bad on multiple levels. First, the scheduling process is so unprofessional and inconsiderate that I thought it was a mistake at first. employees were given less than 24 hours notice of their schedules, in some cases requiring them to cancel the plans they had for the VERY NEXT DAY because they were told on a Friday that their schedule includes weekends. No acknowledgement of that whatsoever from management. Second, most of the supervisors I worked with don't respond to their emails, messages, etc. Third, the technical incompetence of some members of management is staggering - I had a supervisor dump a complex project on my team without providing us any of the resources we needed to execute it, and then completely stop responding to our messages. 

This is not a place you want to be working. Keep looking.

pros:
It doesn't get better than PIH's mission: working to provide a preferential option for the poor by doing whatever it takes to help local ministries of health provide the highest standards of health care in remote, rural areas where few other organizations work.  This mission pulls in wonderful people, and one of the delights of working at PIH is the strength, intelligence, wisdom, and passion of many of our colleagues around the world.

Despite the challenges noted below, the work is incredibly rewarding: especially for staff members who are able to stick with the organization over a long time horizon, it's exciting to see the frustrating two-steps-forward-and-one-step-back process slowly but surely adding up into better health care and more resilient systems for the people we serve.
cons:
Working in the midst of scarce resources is intensely difficult and PIH's ambitions sometimes outstrip our organizational capacity to fully live up to our mission across the wide variety of places where we work.  We often under-staff projects because of limited budgets and the strongest staff members tend to be committed to too many different initiatives, which can in turn make them less effective and less responsive than ideal.  

With everyone so stretched thin, effective organizational management can often take a back seat to fighting fires--and because we work in places that are extremely vulnerable to natural and man-made disasters, there are always many fires to fight.  All of this adds up to an environment that can be stressful to work in, and can create misunderstandings and frustrations between colleagues, especially since so much collaboration is done long-distance and across language and cultural boundaries.

As others have noted in reviews, PIH also struggles with creating a diversity and inclusion environment that lives up to our organizational ideals.  From my perspective, there are two major roots to our challenges: first, even people with strong social justice ideals have biases, cultural blind spots, and are fallible, especially under the pressures of this work.  Second, PIH has grown so quickly that our systems are not fully formed to effectively address (or prevent) challenges in maintaining a truly diverse workforce and an inclusive environment for all staff.  That being said, it seems like our Executive Leadership team is taking these issues seriously and are starting to put stronger systems in place, led by an excellent Director of Diversity and Inclusion who was hired last year.

pros: A lot of young, bright, fun staff. The core mission and approach to global health that PIH supports and promotes is great.
cons: It's a very political environment and there are a lot of egos. It is also a super elitist organization - a lot of staff that privilege their Ivy League educations. There is no structure for career growth for junior staff - management just assumes (and therefore promotes) that all junior staff is just young people who will go to grad school in a few years. Because of this attitude, turnover is extremely high. Most people working there today, weren't there 3 years ago. The effect this has this has on the whole organization and the lost institutional knowledge is profound.There is no project/program management and no real evaluation of the majority of our programs. After being around for almost 30 years, discussions around this and the complete lack of grant managemt are just beginning. Because of this lack of a clear program management structure, there is zero accountability. Much of the fundraising staff has, despite their best efforts, never even visited a site. review_title: Avoid - this was the most disorganized work environment I've ever seen
pros: When people cooperate and put aside egos, good work can be done. The local country staff in Haiti and Africa are often incredible, dedicated people, and they do a lot of great work for relatively small pay.
cons:
The organization is a shell of what it once was, and due to a lack of coordinated management is a mess. Senior leadership, both directors and managers, who were around for 7-10 years, were good at what they did and were dedicated to the causes that PIH promotes, have been either fired outright or pushed out in a passive/aggressive manner over the past 3-5 years. What is left behind are wealthy former investment firm managers and similar people who have been newly hired to serve as PIH's leadership team on development, communications, evaluation, HR and other teams. They don't really understand the work that is being done in the field, and their arrogance is off-putting to the staff in developing countries. To the Boston staff they are aloof at best and shockingly ignorant of the most basic global health knowledge at worst.

There is no clear direction given to employees, and the organization operates in a very haphazard manner. As a result of constant budget cuts, threats of layoffs, overwhelming egos and infighting, the staff does not work cooperatively even though many of them are good people. The lack of structure and leadership results in confusion and a lot of animosity, and the work suffers as a result. Turnover is overwhelming and constant. During the past 3 years, several positions have turned over more than three times (that is, many people staying less than a year). It is sad, because this used to be a good place to work, even though the pay may have been low and the pace hectic, at least it stood for something. That strong sense of purpose is now overwhelmed by egotistical directors who simply do not grasp the work that needs to be done, a lack of leadership and a non-existent management structure.

pros: Programs are impactful and the opportunity to do meaningful field work is extremely high. Staff is smart and capable.

Overall there is a complete mismatch in the board and leadership and goals.

review_title: Inspiring field work; toxic HQ office environment
pros: The mission and values and the vast majority of the people you work with are all wonderful and inspiring -- especially as it pertains to the field work. What we do on the ground is truly amazing. I've long said that it seems a prerequisite for working here is that you must be a genuinely nice person down to your core, and you can see that in about 99% of the people you work with.
cons:
I really didn't want to throw gasoline on this fire, but it seems Executive Leadership is just not getting the memo (or doesn't care) about the toxic environment in the Boston office. Sadly, a few sour apples are ruining the bunch -- especially in the Boston office. Shortly after moving into a beautiful new office space in Back Bay, we learned the organization was in a massive budget crisis, and a hiring and travel freeze was put in place. Morale plummeted as numerous colleagues and friends were laid off, fired, or just jumped ship. Now that we are "running lean," work-life balance seems a figment of the imagination, and a formerly collaborative and friendly environment has shifted to a stressful "every man for himself" situation. While the shake-up in staff hasn't been completely terrible, and we are now bringing in new hires who all seem to be pretty great, there remains little opportunity for advancement for those who have weathered the storm (unless your boss jumps ship, and you're left trying to pick up the pieces). There is very little investment in supporting people's professional development, or even trying to help inexperienced managers acclimate to roles that fell unexpectedly into their laps. Many managers are wonderful, a few are horrible, and there is no real way to address any problems. For all the talk of diversity and inclusion, empowering the little guy, and social justice -- the Boston office is oppressively hierarchical. Whatever the boss-man says, goes -- even if it's obviously not the right move, may be hurting more than it's helping, or could potentially be out of alignment with MA employment law. When people raise concerns about unfair treatment or inconsistent application of policy, they are shut down, shut out, and essentially gaslighted until they leave on their own or are fired.

HR is truly horrific. I second the other reviewer's report on HR participating in name-calling, having experienced this first-hand on a number of occasions. While there is one guy in that department who is truly wonderful, warm, compassionate, and has a sincere desire to help -- he has no real power to affect change, even when he tries. Others on his team are either woefully incompetent or seem to be in willful denial of any problems that come to their attention. Serious procedures you would absolutely expect to have a policy guiding their implementation are completely devoid of such. If a manager wants to get back at an employee for raising genuine concerns in a diplomatic way, that manager can definitely do that with impunity. Employees have to beg and plead for help from HR, only to discover that such assistance, if provided, is hollow at best -- and at worst, could completely backfire, making matters worse than they already were.

review_title: Very bad environment in the Boston office
pros:
The mission to help the poor of many countries is strong and important to support. the vision of the founders is innovative and unique.
good place to get an immersion in global health, but would be much better to get an opportunity in one of the country-based programs rather than in this US office.
cons:
CEO is unable to manage the toxic work environment in the expensive-to-lease Boston office. (The lease is convenient because its steps from his home so I guess its ok for him and the leadership team that it costs $25 to park for the day, when most of the employees are on minimum wage). "let them take the MBTA then!" Expensive prime real estate is at odds with mission to serve the worlds poorest people. 

The office environment is toxic to people of color, and to women. Women are called emotional. Most POC have been either harassed out of the office or fired over the last 2 years. There are currently only a small number of managers of color. But you can expect platitudes and false statements about diversity. A diversity and inclusion officer was hired and is a life-saver, kind, thoughtful, compassionate and knowledgeable, but was quickly dis-empowered so its hard for him to make any changes. 

HR is not competent in managing simple issues like withholding taxes for expatriate workers or in dealing with reports of conflict.  And does not follow up on reports of racist behavior. Has been known to participate in name-calling.

The medical directors office is chaotic and is routinely no-show for meetings, always late, double-booked, more interested in promoting herself in a movie than actually getting things done. 

The board is great at raising money, but don't get involved in the serious issues in management.
